commit_message:
Add share server migration

This patch adds support for migration of share servers. This
migration is performed using a two-phase approach. Administrators
are now able to request the migration of a share server within and
across backends, with the possibility of chooosing a different share
network for the destination share server.

- A new field called `task_state` was added to the share server
  model in order to help the administrator to track the share server
  migration steps. A new field called `source_share_server_id` was
  added to link destination and source share servers.

- A new periodic task was added to track migration of share servers
  and its resources.

- Two new states were added: `server_migrating` and
  `server_migrating_to` to represent that share migration is in
  progress.

- When performing the server migration, manila will not go to the
  scheduler, instead it will provide a request spec to drivers
  during migration check driver call. It'll be up to the driver
  validate if there is free space to handle the share server.

- A new API called `share-server-migration-check' was added to
  check the feasibility of a migration, before actually triggering
  the start operation.

APIImpact
DocImpact
Partially Implements: bp share-server-migration

Co-Authored-By: Andre Beltrami <debeltrami@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Carlos Eduardo <ces.eduardo98@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Felipe Rodrigues <felipefuty01@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ic0751027d2c3f1ef7ab0f7836baff3070a230cfd
Signed-off-by: Douglas Viroel <viroel@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add 'agent_token' to heartbeat request

Updates the API ref to include the 'agent_token' value in a
heartbeat request (from IPA). New since v1.62
(https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/9341ca4ef726826f4845635e6567a919f2ddc48c/ironic/api/controllers/v1/versions.py#L102).

Change-Id: I5eea9704c1bf62561a5505227735159dad7a8e49

Stop install unnecessary packages when run tox -edocs

when run tox -e docs. docs relative stuffs is in doc/requirements.txt,

- Add some helpful descriptions for the various environments
- Use lower-case boolean values (they're prettier)
- Remove some unnecessary warning filters for issues not present on
  Python 3.6+
- Move the 'venv' target to the end of the file, indicating its priority

commit_message:
tox: Trivial cleanup

- Add some helpful descriptions for the various environments
- Use lower-case boolean values (they're prettier)
- Remove some unnecessary warning filters for issues not present on
  Python 3.6+
- Move the 'venv' target to the end of the file, indicating its priority
  (quite low)
- Fix a bit of wonky indentation

Change-Id: Ia083f959d2a9c974b4c0592fdada21dcc766dca4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

subject: tox: Add functional-pyNN targets
messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-08-07 09:38:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-08-07 13:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 32029, 'date': '2020-09-04 06:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 32291, 'date': '2020-09-04 07:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2020-09-11 04:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-07 09:38:18.000000000', 'message': "tox: Add functional-pyNN targets

tox isn't all that clever when it comes to handling non-existent
environments with multiple factors. Without these explicit
'functional-pyNN' targets explicitly defined, attempting to run e.g.
'tox -e functional-py36' will actually end up running the default
'testenv', which run *unit* tests. This is almost certainly a bug in
tox, but we need to fix it here to get functional tests passing again.

Change-Id: If47eb0da2b04d7a288f53e80f0addd72edcd9e7a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
tox: Add functional-pyNN targets

tox isn't all that clever when it comes to handling non-existent
environments with multiple factors. Without these explicit
'functional-pyNN' targets explicitly defined, attempting to run e.g.
'tox -e functional-py36' will actually end up running the default
'testenv', which run *unit* tests. This is almost certainly a bug in
tox, but we need to fix it here to get functional tests passing again.

Change-Id: If47eb0da2b04d7a288f53e80f0addd72edcd9e7a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.


Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal.h>

Change-Id: I97072055f880915cef6c5c2f0210730e7bbe5119

subject: Update the lbaas security group only if the service policy is enabled.
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-10 11:57:08.000000000', 'message': 'Update the lbaas security group only if the service policy is enabled.

When handler of policy is enabled and pod_security_groups_driver is policy but but handler of service is disabled ,kuryr-controller start failed.
It should be adapted to cases when service handler is disabled and policy is enabled for pod.

Closes-Bug: 1895100

Change-Id: I662828e54363fb028ae8fcafdb7ca2a9fcc1d8bb
'}]
commit_message:
Update the lbaas security group only if the service policy is enabled.

When handler of policy is enabled and pod_security_groups_driver is policy but but handler of service is disabled ,kuryr-controller start failed.
It should be adapted to cases when service handler is disabled and policy is enabled for pod.

Closes-Bug: 1895100

Change-Id: I662828e54363fb028ae8fcafdb7ca2a9fcc1d8bb

(6 comments)

@stephen, thanks for your review.

Basically I don't use 'cleanup' because original code not using it, I don't know why original code just calls 'delete_instance_files', not sure if there is some potential issues to call 'cleanup' for incomplete migrations.

I go through the 'cleanup' code (libvirt driver) and many questions appears in my mind if we simply call 'cleanup'. There are several parameters in 'cleanup' function
1.block_device_info:
indicate if we need disconnect volume (we need get bdm info first)
2.destroy_disks:
indicate if we need destroy volumes and delete instance files
3.destroy_vifs
indicate if we need unplug vifs (we need get network info first)

should we cleanup all these things? Besides, one more question at the end of the 'cleanup' is the domain will be undefined also, is it ok to undefine the domain for incomplete migrations? Actually I can't get a certain answer by myself."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-09-10 16:20:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

 > 2.destroy_disks:
 > indicate if we need destroy volumes and delete instance files
 > 3.destroy_vifs

 > 
 > should we cleanup all these things? Besides, one more question at
 > the end of the 'cleanup' is the domain will be undefined also, is
 > it ok to undefine the domain for incomplete migrations? Actually I
 > can't get a certain answer by myself.

Okay, given how late we are in the day for this, I guess that's an investigation we'll have to do later. This is good enough for now. Thanks for the continued worked on this"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:56:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Track error migrations in resource tracker

If rollback_live_migration failed, the migration status is set to
'error', and there might me some resource not be cleaned up like vpmem
since rollback is not completed. So we propose to track those 'error'
migrations in resource tracker until they are cleaned up by periodic
task '_cleanup_incomplete_migrations'.

So if rollback_live_migration succeeds, we need to set the migration
status to 'failed' which will not be tracked in resource tracker. The
'failed' status is already used for resize to indicated a migration
finishing the cleanup.

'_cleanup_incomplete_migrations' will also handle failed
rollback_live_migration cleanup except for failed resize/revert-resize.

Besides, we introduce a new 'cleanup_lingering_instance_resources' virt
driver interface to handle lingering instance resources cleanup
including vpmem cleanup and whatever we add in the future.

Change-Id: I422a907056543f9bf95acbffdd2658438febf801
Partially-Implements: blueprint vpmem-enhancement

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal.h>

Change-Id: Id6b499239fa8b6480c5f67d460215ab458677c6d

I think you should wait.

the only thing I can see happening is that when I put out 1.4 betas, other folks in openstack land are going to come over and try to implement this same thing as they see oslo.db isn't going to work, so we just have to watch for that and make sure this approach is merged when folks are coming around wondering why oslo.db doesnt work with SQLAlchemy 1.4."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-09-08 15:16:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal.h>

I wondering if we should wait a bit for this.

Some requirements have been bumped (tenacity) if some for some reasons we need to release a new version with a bugfix then we will need to release a minor version due to the requirement update.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-07 13:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

this is needed for Victoria gate also to keep that green when base jobs will migrate to Focal. We can either take this as FFE or backport which is something I would like to discuss in today oslo meeting. either way is ok for me.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-07 13:33:46.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from migrate-to-focal to migrate-to-focal-oslo'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-09-07 14:54:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal.h>

Change-Id: I18419ce93363fbf2eed174e81ed212ddae216b8c

Code looks sane, I'm testing it locally in my env now. Question, where I can find previous discussions on the design for this new UI component? I'm working on the Manila UI implementation for this same feature and it would be nice to be consistent on how we display information, so if there is something already discussed I'd like to check it out. Personally I find it a bit odd that user messages are display for each resource individually. Me, as an operator, would like to see messages in a single place. But probably you discussed about this. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2020-07-22 13:15:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> Code looks sane, I'm testing it locally in my env now. Question,
 > where I can find previous discussions on the design for this new UI
 > component? I'm working on the Manila UI implementation for this
 > same feature and it would be nice to be consistent on how we
 > display information, so if there is something already discussed I'd
 > like to check it out. Personally I find it a bit odd that user
 > messages are display for each resource individually. Me, as an
 > operator, would like to see messages in a single place. But
 > probably you discussed about this. Thanks!

Hi Victoria, thanks for showing interest in this bp.
You can find some irc discussions here [1], [2]:
[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-horizon/%23openstack-horizon.2020-07-01.log.html#t2020-07-01T12:01:14
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-meeting-alt/%23openstack-meeting-alt.2020-07-01.log.html#t2020-07-01T15:53:34"}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2020-07-28 20:06:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Vishal, following with the discussion, we are implementing the same feature in Manila and I proposed an initial draft here https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742550/. I was wondering which would be the most usable approach. Maybe a combination of both? Having a single point in which all messages can be inspected and also have messages per resources. I'd love to hear your thoughts :)"}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-08-05 08:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add cinder-user-facing messages

This patch adds a tab for cinder user messages for volumes and
snapshots. Cinder user messages shows error details for cinder
resources like if we are unable to create a volume due to some
failure in cinder it will shows us the reason of failure.

Implements blueprint cinder-user-facing-messages

Change-Id: I6f1539ffebdf2dfd0a470009e9171e868c2a9ad3

commit_message:
Remove six.PY3

The Python 2.7 Support has been dropped since Ussuri.
So remove hacking rules for compatibility between python 2 and 3.

Change-Id: I5ec70dc8153dc0ab0bf0323ffb814822566da6cc

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40207

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal.h>

Change-Id: Iade03cf85b4f09ce2e8d4f6d9a06635b263f6a79

subject: Revert "Run openstack-tox-lower-constraints on bionic"
messages:
[{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

An explanation of why in the commit would be good, but I don't think this should be reverted. Our lower constraints should run on our lowest sorted versions."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Fungi has pointed out that the QA team has been tasked with managing this transition by the TC. The Infra team should defer to that and project teams like cinder can work with the QA and TC to figure out how lower constraints should be tested.

Also, cinder could do a lower-constraints job variant temporarily to work around this (though that may require dropping the use of templates and adding all those jobs back in).'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:43:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ghanshyam: can you improve the commit message on this with some rationale?

As Clark stated, it's been convention that the TC has delegated project-wide testing decision to the QA team (except as expressly spelled out in the PTI), so for an OpenStack-wide standard job it's their call until the TC says otherwise. A separate Cinder-specific lower-constraints job using ubuntu-bionic nodes and Python 3.6 instead of running the standard one is also something I would approve from a Cinder infra liaison, again unless the TC said otherwise."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-11 00:24:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-09-11 00:25:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-09-11 00:58:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow+1

Carrying over Clark's earlier +2 from before the commit message improvement.

I'm sympathetic to the arguments on both sides, but ultimately it's the TC's choice to either support or overrule the QA team's decisions and PTI interpretation where standard jobs used by many different OpenStack projects are concerned."}]

commit_message:
Revert "Run openstack-tox-lower-constraints on bionic"

This reverts commit 9a491100278eccc40219f51a329c0d0980a3d8a6.

As per the Focal migration work, most of the projects have been fixed
for running the l-c job on Focal[1].

As part of this migration, l-c testing the min version of deps can work
on tested Distro which is Focal in this. If I am installing Nova on Focal
then I will be ineterested to see what all min version of Nova deps can
work in Focal. We can debate on this if we need to test on any older distro
which as per supported python or any other distro and accordingly we can
test the l-c job accordingly. But for this in middle of migration we should
keep it tested on Focal compatible.

Cinder and Keystone projects are two main project failing on l-c, let's
keep running their l-c jobs in Bionic
- cinder: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/751118/
- keystone: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/751122/


[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-September/017155.html
Change-Id: I34ef635d1987bde03fe5944f511dfe7ec1fb741f

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iedf7185b12426eee73952a51edd4f64060b37702

commit_message:
Add paramiko version atleast 2.7.0 in requirement.txt

we see paramiko version 2.4.0 installed in OSP deployment
downstream that doesn't support OPENSSH key type which is the
default one genrated through ssh-keygen and thus ssh to all the
nodes are failing leads to all the whitebox test failing that required
ssh to hypervisor.

The paramiko has already added support of OPENSSH key type from
2.7.0 onwards[1], so updating the version in requirement.txt

[1]: http://www.paramiko.org/changelog.html

Change-Id: Ie58c979b269088ddcde3eebd1972cd9d7370087b

commit_message:
[DNM] [ovn] PLEASE IGNORE. This will not be merged in stable branches

Fix definition of the fip_pf_description api extension

In this extension "description" field should be added in the
SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP rather than in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.
It also should be added in "parameters" dict which is inside
SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.

Change-Id: Ifcb0d81eafe65696401954055b9d29b36d2d397a
Related-Bug: #1866560
(cherry picked from commit 80bccac9b84f7ba7518126b6ad1f868b6bbc87b8)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-09 13:12:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add description field in port forwarding API

Problem Description
===================

As users create and update theirs floating ip rules, the reason
behind those rules might get lost throughout time. Moreover, in
an environment with many people writing rules, it is important
to track down the reason behind each one of the rules
created/added in a floating IP port forwarding configuration.
The addition of a description field would allow operators to
determine the reason why a rule was created and help the users
to know if the existence of a rule is still reasonable.

Proposed Change
===============

To address the described scenario, we propose to create a new
“description” field in the Neutron’s Floating IP port forwarding
rules API JSON. This new field will be a nullable String
containing the description/reason why this new port forwarding
rule is being created.

Change-Id: If98a70011b187d2143a660f1f281ab197d21eb4d
Implements: blueprint portforwarding-description
Closes-Bug: #1850818
(cherry picked from commit a37378e8d50e074667a55784758790b2929d75a6)
'}, {'created': '2020-09-09 13:15:54.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] [ovn] PLEASE IGNORE. This will not be merged in stable branches

Problem Description
===================

As users create and update theirs floating ip rules, the reason
behind those rules might get lost throughout time. Moreover, in

created/added in a floating IP port forwarding configuration.
The addition of a description field would allow operators to
determine the reason why a rule was created and help the users

Proposed Change

To address the described scenario, we propose to create a new
“description” field in the Neutron’s Floating IP port forwarding

containing the description/reason why this new port forwarding
rule is being created.

Change-Id: If98a70011b187d2143a660f1f281ab197d21eb4d
Implements: blueprint portforwarding-description
Closes-Bug: #1850818
(cherry picked from commit a37378e8d50e074667a55784758790b2929d75a6)

commit_message:
[DNM] [ovn] PLEASE IGNORE. This will not be merged in stable branches

Add description field in port forwarding API

Problem Description
===================

As users create and update theirs floating ip rules, the reason
behind those rules might get lost throughout time. Moreover, in
an environment with many people writing rules, it is important
to track down the reason behind each one of the rules
created/added in a floating IP port forwarding configuration.
The addition of a description field would allow operators to
determine the reason why a rule was created and help the users
to know if the existence of a rule is still reasonable.

Proposed Change
===============

To address the described scenario, we propose to create a new
“description” field in the Neutron’s Floating IP port forwarding
rules API JSON. This new field will be a nullable String
containing the description/reason why this new port forwarding
rule is being created.

Change-Id: If98a70011b187d2143a660f1f281ab197d21eb4d
Implements: blueprint portforwarding-description
Closes-Bug: #1850818
(cherry picked from commit a37378e8d50e074667a55784758790b2929d75a6)

[{'created': '2020-09-03 21:39:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add openstack/osops

This adds a new repo to combine the several x/osops-* repos into one
repo owned by the Operation Docs and Tooling SIG as a place to collect
scripts, code snippets, configs, and any other useful tools for
operators.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-August/016858.html

commit_message:
Add openstack/osops

This adds a new repo to combine the several x/osops-* repos into one
repo owned by the Operation Docs and Tooling SIG as a place to collect
scripts, code snippets, configs, and any other useful tools for
operators.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-August/016858.html

Needed-by: https://review.opendev.org/749835

Change-Id: I1d2c40a0b07e7e0816d4381253655bd05ff2ab79
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Release final python-ironic-inspector-client for victoria

Final victoria client lib release for the September 10 deadline.

Please leave +1 if we are all set and can proceed. Leave a -1 if we
need to wait a little bit longer for something final to loand,
then update with a better commit hash to use for the release when
ready.

Patches with no response will be approved by September 14.

Change-Id: I1cf9e0b27b7c758f357513532f22ff51c0cf0ded
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
[Cinder] Support for external ceph backend

This is to add support for external ceph cluster as second backend
for cinder.

prerequisite:
  - create ceph.conf for external ceph cluster as configmap
  - create cinder2 user and keyring on external ceph cluster
  - create keyring of user cinder2 as a secret

now point configmap and secret created as prerequisite under
values.ceph_client.external_ceph section

also we need to add second backend under values.conf.backends section
with all the details of external ceph cluster.

Change-Id: I8df9f1da7208304f479dbb70b19af97fb01cd38f

(1 comment)

Need to use numeric comparisons.

The comment applies to all the places where it occurs, but in particular, if I render this locally with helm client v2.13.1, it reports Capabilities.KubeVersion.Major as "9", which is greater than "15" in a string comparison, so it gives me an unexpected result.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-18 19:51:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-18 19:52:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 05:33:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 06:25:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28719, 'date': '2019-11-20 07:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (1 comment)

After testing this further and reviewing the deprecation documentation, I think the ClusterRole should unconditionally include both apiGroups to allow the resources to be accessed from either API endpoint, at least until v1.20 when they will no longer be served.

      - "extensions"
      - "networking.k8s.io"

In that case, the version check is limited to ingress.yaml and _ingress.tpl.

I'm not sure if explicitly specifying the version would work for the helm-toolkit manifest used by other charts. What if we move the check to a snippet that could be leveraged by ingress.yaml and _ingress.tpl, maybe something like:

    {{- define "helm-toolkit.snippets.ingress_apiversion" -}}
    {{- if or ( gt (int .Capabilities.KubeVersion.Major) 1) ( and (eq (int .Capabilities.KubeVersion.Major) 1) (gt (int .Capabilities.KubeVersion.Minor) 15) ) }}
    apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1beta1
    {{- else }}
    apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
    {{- end }}
    {{- end -}}'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 07:56:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 07:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 08:01:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 08:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 23:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-20 23:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-21 00:33:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 18511, 'date': '2019-11-21 03:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2019-11-21 04:29:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 17119, 'date': '2019-11-22 07:11:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 18511, 'date': '2019-11-22 12:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2019-11-22 17:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29974, 'date': '2019-12-16 16:36:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28719, 'date': '2019-12-16 17:19:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

The changes in ingress version and k8s are tied together closely. Do the RBAC rules here support a wide enough range of of versions?

k8s 1.14.0 made the ingress api accessible via both networking.k8s.io and extensions.

nginx 0.25.0 introduced the "breaking change" where it actually tries to use the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1

https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/releases/tag/nginx-0.25.0'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:57:30.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
[Ingress] Update apiVersion for Ingress resource

The PS updates apiVersion for ingress resources according to
the changes in Kubernetes v1.16.0 ("networking.k8s.io/v1beta1").

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/release-1.16/CHANGELOG-1.16.md
Section "Deprecations and Removals"

Change-Id: I358b84858e42142c593868ca95179a73f9bb0c6d

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Modify cinder_storage_init scripts because that can make parsing error

In cinder_storage_init scripts that use 'ceph osd pool' command,
However, I notice that Parsing can make issue, If rbd_chunk_size is not justified,
then rbd_app_name goes to position of rbd_chunk_size, And origin rbd_app_size position is emptied,
So I change parsing into real value use.

Change-Id: I8257f9a3dcd79bfe983e5c78d81adb47bf694416
Story: 2007011
Task: 37796

This is an instance where an explicit solution is far better than an implicit solution.'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2019-03-27 20:48:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> This can be achieved by using a different FROM image, with the code
 > checked-in.

Yes this might be achieved by using pre-create FROM image but content will be added there with same ADD directive we don't want to pass credentials inside docker as they will be available in image history. Still we need change to `scripts/clone_project.sh` what is the actual benefit in other temporary image?"}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2019-03-27 20:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Chris, Jean-Philippe thanks for review I appreciate it.'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-05-04 16:16:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-05-04 16:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2019-05-04 16:22:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

I'm fine with this patch. We need to add documentation on what the data directory is for and how it relates to downloading the project."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-10 10:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I am fine with this. I think it's by far more elegant than adding extra packages into the build system. Please see my comment to upgrade my vote."}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2019-12-12 20:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:57:20.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
Allow to pass project from external directory

This patch allows to pass directory with source code of
projects to conteiner during build. This is useful when
it is not possible to clone project in anonymous mode.

Change-Id: Id157ad614b790a87d8c8910a438a29887f9fc46e

commit_message:
Add elasticsearch query script to elasticsearch chart

This adds a bash script to the elasticsearch chart that provides
a simple interface for querying the elasticsearch cluster for
logged events, based on labels and the corresponding message field
for the specific events desired

Change-Id: I75bd40ed2a5272c15fdd9bc217bd7944f1a2ec7f
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

subject: Fix Flake F811 for microversioned methods
messages: [{'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2020-09-10 18:08:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2020-09-10 20:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2020-09-10 22:43:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-10 18:08:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Flake F811 for microversioned methods

CI/CD jobs were switch to Ubuntu Focal (20.04) [1] which caused flake to
flag F811 errors for methods with duplicate names.  These methods are
actually microversioned, so this should not be flagged.  Adding noqa for
F811 to avoid getting flagged by flake.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-September/017104.html

Change-Id: I8e12127bf331f37d1a826ce7f0296183df2ba181
'}, {'created': '2020-09-10 20:14:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Flake F811 for microversioned methods

CI/CD jobs were switch to Ubuntu Focal (20.04) [1] which caused flake to
flag F811 errors for methods with duplicate names.  These methods are
actually microversioned, so this should not be flagged.  Adding noqa for
F811 to avoid getting flagged by flake.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-September/017104.html

Change-Id: I8e12127bf331f37d1a826ce7f0296183df2ba181
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Flake F811 for microversioned methods

CI/CD jobs were switch to Ubuntu Focal (20.04) [1] which caused flake to
flag F811 errors for methods with duplicate names.  These methods are
actually microversioned, so this should not be flagged.  Adding noqa for
F811 to avoid getting flagged by flake.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-September/017104.html

Change-Id: I8e12127bf331f37d1a826ce7f0296183df2ba181

detach seamed to work and correctly freed the pci claim

but attaching the interface again failed with 
http://paste.openstack.org/show/796025/

in this case i booted a vm with 2 VF on vnic_type=direct and the other vnic_type=macvtap

i detached the macvtap and tied to attach it agian.
the detach succeeded but it looks like the interface was not unplugged as the macvtap interface on the host was not removed.
a hard reboot fixed that and allowed the macvtap to be reattached.

doing the same for the vnic_type=direct interface seams to work fine but is suspect we are not calling unplug in both cases meaning if if truested_vfs was requested it would not be unset on detach.

if we are not calling unplug on detach in this case then we would not delete the ovs port for hardware offloaded ovs either.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-07-16 19:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

on other thing i just noticed is we also do not remove the vf configuretion correclty means that it still has the neutron port mac on the vm and its still on the correct vlan meaning that when its detached 
it potentally allows access via that ip to the host.
so that would be a security issue. as other vms on the same tenant network could potentially acess the host via that port.

it would also cause a network parttion in some cases if  the neutron port was reused for another vm on a different host.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-07-17 15:57:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

This unfuctnetly does not correctly detach the interface form the libvirt xml in the macvtap or driect physical case

in the macvtap case this leave teh vf configured with the neutorn prot mac and vlan which would be a security issue

detail are here
http://paste.openstack.org/show/796572/'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-08-05 11:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> This unfuctnetly does not correctly detach the interface form the
 > libvirt xml in the macvtap or driect physical case
 > 
 > in the macvtap case this leave teh vf configured with the neutorn
 > prot mac and vlan which would be a security issue
 > 
 > detail are here
 > http://paste.openstack.org/show/796572/

I cannot reproduce your failures in my env. See http://paste.openstack.org/show/796598/ for details.

I'm wondering if your first error: "libvirt.libvirtError: Unable to get index for interface eth3: No such device" might be an indication that you are not starting from a clean state. As far as I understand the name "eth3" is not coming from nova or os-vif at all. So it might be a confusion on the libvirt side on your host
Btw I'm using libvirt 6.0.0 and qemu 4.2 in my env.

For the macvtap detach case: I can attach and detach macvtaps without problem in my env with the current PS. If the macvtap detach silently failing for you then I would try to trace the device matching logic here https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740995/6/nova/virt/libvirt/config.py@1670 

For the mactap detach MAC case: I see that the macvtap device was removed from the host but the VF, the macvtap used , still has the MAC of the neutron port. Who should clean this up? Libvirt? Neutron? Nova?

For the direct-physical detach case: This also works for me properly. In your env I would try to trace the device match at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740995/6/nova/virt/libvirt/config.py@2116'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2020-08-05 13:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

'}, {'created': '2020-08-03 16:23:53.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support SRIOV interface attach and detach

For attach:
* Generates InstancePciRequest for SRIOV interfaces requests
* Claims and allocates PciDevice for the request

For detach:
* Frees PciDevice and deletes the InstancePciRequests
* Fixes PCI address generation to avoid double 0x prefixes in LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI
* Adds support for comparing LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI objects
* Extends the comparison of LibvirtConfigGuestInterface to support
  macvtap interfaces where target_dev is only known by libvirt but not
  nova
* generalize guest.get_interface_by_cfg() to work with both
  LibvirtConfigGuest[Inteface|HostdevPCI]

     works.

commit_message:
Support SRIOV interface attach and detach

For attach:
* Generates InstancePciRequest for SRIOV interfaces attach requests
* Claims and allocates a PciDevice for such request

For detach:
* Frees PciDevice and deletes the InstancePciRequests

On the libvirt driver side the following small fixes was necessar:
* Fixes PCI address generation to avoid double 0x prefixes in LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI
* Adds support for comparing LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI objects
* Extends the comparison of LibvirtConfigGuestInterface to support
  macvtap interfaces where target_dev is only known by libvirt but not
  nova
* generalize guest.get_interface_by_cfg() to work with both
  LibvirtConfigGuest[Inteface|HostdevPCI] objects

Implements: blueprint sriov-interface-attach-detach

Change-Id: I67504a37b0fe2ae5da3cba2f3122d9d0e18b9481

subject: Run openstack-tox-lower-constraints on bionic

This seems fine as a short-term fix, but longer term if projects are going to declare support for older platforms than what's in our tested runtime recommendations, it would be good to make sure guidance from QA and the TC takes this into account."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:16:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This seems fine as a short-term fix, but longer term if projects
 > are going to declare support for older platforms than what's in our
 > tested runtime recommendations, it would be good to make sure
 > guidance from QA and the TC takes this into account.

well, I think main goal for l-c is what all min version of deps can be used for project on same platform. For example if I run Nova on Focal then lower constraints tested has to be min compatible version on Focal not Bionic. I think we have to ake l-c compatible for Focal other wise we can break many other project if already fixed l-c for many projects goes incompatible with Bionic"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as I34ef635d1987bde03fe5944f511dfe7ec1fb741f'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-09-10 23:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It may make sense to run this on centos-8 instead of bionic so we test on a declared distro.'}]

[{'created': '2020-09-10 21:20:57.000000000', 'message': 'Run openstack-tox-lower-constraints on bionic

The lower-constraints job is to test our minimum values. Since py3.6 is
our minimum runtime, these jobs should run there rather than the latest
and greatest. This updates the job definition to use bionic nodes.

Change-Id: Ia9beee908cbb4865cecc07c6c7384e1cb6e76bde
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Run openstack-tox-lower-constraints on bionic

The lower-constraints job is to test our minimum values. Since py3.6 is
our minimum runtime, these jobs should run there rather than the latest
and greatest. This updates the job definition to use bionic nodes.

Change-Id: Ia9beee908cbb4865cecc07c6c7384e1cb6e76bde
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-03 09:46:00.000000000', 'message': 'Capacity based QoS doc

The Cinder Capacity based quality of service documentation does not
provide enough information to understand difference between
options to control capacity based quality of service.

These option can categorized into dynamic and minimum IOPS per volume
and dynamic and minimum bandwidth per volume.

Change-Id: If45b7a13ffc4311df43dbd241c305b74675a408d
Closes-Bug: #1894072
'}]
commit_message:
Capacity based QoS doc

The Cinder Capacity based quality of service documentation does not
provide enough information to understand difference between
options to control capacity based quality of service.

These option can categorized into dynamic and minimum IOPS per volume
and dynamic and minimum bandwidth per volume.

Change-Id: If45b7a13ffc4311df43dbd241c305b74675a408d
Closes-Bug: #1894072

commit_message:
Bump pyroute2 upper constraint to 0.5.14

Version 0.5.13 of pyroute2 had a regression[1] that broke Octavia,
but it also contained a fix required for neutron.
This patch bumps pyroute2 to 0.5.14 to fix the regression.

[1] https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/pull/725

Change-Id: I1959152e35557e61857d5f3f6e6146e8abe11ea8

commit_message:
Don't store signal_url for ec2 signaling of deployments

As part of a CVE keystone has started checking[1] the timestamp
of signed ec2 token with default TTL of 15 mins. We can't
store the ec2 url anymore for future use for those.

This moves the caching logic to BaseWaitConditionHandle class.

Conflicts:
	heat/engine/resources/signal_responder.py
	heat/tests/test_signal.py

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/724124/

Change-Id: I6b74faed820caccd39210bd48a212b2dedca46b9
Task: 39985
Related-Bug: #1872737
(cherry picked from commit 3047ca7d36baaa59ab2960602da956d2087a2a62)
(cherry picked from commit 913c428b3030c67b3110af75f24dd8f99be00dbf)

commit_message:
Remove unused "_ping_host_from_export_location" method

There is an other method for pinging to the export location,
called "validate_ping_to_export_location".

Change-Id: Ia23b11fec8ac3a36d4c424c50129523ad3b7e912

commit_message:
Add requirements for jobboard drivers

As Octavia allows to use RedisTaskFlowDriver or
ZookeeperTaskFlowDriver we should install python clients that
allows to work with redis and zookeeper backends.

Story: 2007892

Change-Id: I7312c8c1057618e909339aa7a4dfeb836f4b8f33

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints errors

This patch changes the lower-constraint requirements to make them
py3.8 compatible. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1886298

Markupsafe==1.1.1
PyMySQL==0.8.0
PyYAML==3.13
cffi==1.14.0
greenlet==0.4.15
kombu==5.0.1
lxml==4.5.0
oslo.db==6.0.0
paramiko==2.7.1
psycopg2==2.8
sqlalchemy-migrate==0.13.0
tenacity==6.1.0

Also update the test-setup.sh to work with recent version of mysql.

Change-Id: Ibe60d1e536f0e887eceea32b7cb4eec6318e96af
Partial-Bug: #1886298

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-09 12:39:05.000000000', 'message': 'Set neutron-lib stable ACLs

neutron-lib asserts the stable:follows-policy tag, but the Gerrit ACLs
for the project were never configured to set the stable branch specific
ACLs, including the stable-maint team. This adds the missing
configuration.

https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/reference/projects.yaml#L1132

Change-Id: I26508c96ea7bd0358b1b8510aa8d4f33cc3b0043
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Set neutron-lib stable ACLs

neutron-lib asserts the stable:follows-policy tag, but the Gerrit ACLs
for the project were never configured to set the stable branch specific
ACLs, including the stable-maint team. This adds the missing
configuration.

https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/reference/projects.yaml#L1132

Change-Id: I26508c96ea7bd0358b1b8510aa8d4f33cc3b0043
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Show 'HEALTHY' status in the database service list as a final

Starting with Ussuri 'HEALTHY' is the final status after 'ACTIVE' so we
don't need to show a progress bar in the dashboard.

Change-Id: Iccb1bc78939545a9b8c605efe01c6167c8553597

commit_message:
Disable Zaqar on the Undercloud after Train

Like we did for Mistral in Ib6aaa04a30ad706c5020de7851987fb7455d3136,
let's disable by default the Zaqar service (not needed anymore since we
don't have UI nor Mistral anymore).

Change-Id: Ibf170b1d5fcee23337aa46355b47cbf56fcc2a59

commit_message:
Bump ansible-runner to 1.4.5

There are a few bugs with extra_vars in 1.4.4 which impacts us
at times.

Also bumps some other lower constraints broken due to migration
to ubuntu-focal.

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints errors

This patch changes the lower-constraint requirements to make them
py3.8 compatible. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1886298
cffi==1.14.0
greenlet==0.4.15
MarkupSafe==1.1.0
paramiko==2.7.1
PyYAML==3.13

Change-Id: I826cbbf8072c5b7d533c1e96c9e7ce132a0d9f7e
Closes-Bug: #1895056

commit_message:
Disable tripleo_upgrade_debug

This option adds --debug to the cli command which generates an excessive
amount of logs. We shouldn't have this enabled by default.

Change-Id: I655aa888ca10cc622f80f3f267cdaddf844bdf81

commit_message:
Add tripleo container image hotfix command

Note: this patch has been reworked to work for the stable/queens branch.

This change adds a CLI command to invoke hotfixes via the TripleO modify
image role. This CLI command will ensure a uniform experience for operators
when needing to apply a hotfixes to containers.

Change-Id: I364fb42a41b4cb4ae076f07704c72c6ea442a198
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 182892b1f5d4068621c31b13e9e9c9f04edddb46)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-10 08:19:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add pacemaker& clustercheck in multinode scenario

For train branch, When HA is enabled (Like in Downstream we have HA by
default) - multinode-1ctlr-featureset010 fails with below error:-

~~~
Error: Evaluation Error: Error while evaluating a Function Call,
The $pcs_password param is undefined, did you forget to
include ::tripleo::profile::base::pacemaker in your role?
~~~

With this patch we are adding pacemaker and clustercheck in multinode
ci scenario. Adding them should ideally not impact anything in upstream
as they are mapped to OS::Heat::None for train branch [1][2] in
overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml.

Upstream ussuri+ already have HA as default[3] and these changes are
already present ussuri onwards[4]

[1] https://tinyurl.com/y2jptpsg
[2] https://tinyurl.com/y47agphy
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/359060/
[4] https://tinyurl.com/y2xw6na7

Change-Id: I624cdcd0e22be0378737b635df271fe45b65f9d1
'}]
commit_message:
Add pacemaker& clustercheck in multinode scenario

For train branch, When HA is enabled (Like in Downstream we have HA by
default) - multinode-1ctlr-featureset010 fails with below error:-

~~~
Error: Evaluation Error: Error while evaluating a Function Call,
The $pcs_password param is undefined, did you forget to
include ::tripleo::profile::base::pacemaker in your role?
~~~

With this patch we are adding pacemaker and clustercheck in multinode
ci scenario. Adding them should ideally not impact anything in upstream
as they are mapped to OS::Heat::None for train branch [1][2] in
overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml.

Upstream ussuri+ already have HA as default[3] and these changes are
already present ussuri onwards[4]

[1] https://tinyurl.com/y2jptpsg
[2] https://tinyurl.com/y47agphy
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/359060/
[4] https://tinyurl.com/y2xw6na7

Change-Id: I624cdcd0e22be0378737b635df271fe45b65f9d1

commit_message:
Retire devstack-plugin-pika project

This plugin was used by the oslo.messaging project to test the
development of an alternative RabbitMQ message driver based on
the Pika library (instead of the default Kombu driver).

Development of this driver was dropped in Queens and is not
supported.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/748698/
Change-Id: I5ca41e3d1d55f0ea54dc783d62f37903dcd99c2e

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7f762263c3ab423dd6eea40a596d04ea654a97ea

commit_message:
Update master for stable/victoria

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/victoria.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/victoria.

Change-Id: Ibf43fb846edd1cf76af59aa5e93ccd9de7ffe4c6
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Revert "Use cli-container-image-prepare.yaml playbook"

This reverts commit 8b41b266306984ceda6f571aad195535b3739242.

The switch to ansible has broken the -e argument.
We need to do some more testing before switching
this back as it is not tested in CI.

Change-Id: I57130b1737288b5a3e78b73416cf158c524f0dfa
Closes-Bug: #1895194

commit_message:
Fix Flakes and lower-constraints errors

With the switch to Ubuntu Focal for tox jobs via https://review.opendev.org/#/c/738322/
our 1.1.0 version of hacking pulls in old modules that are not compatible
with python3.8:
https://github.com/openstack/hacking/blob/1.1.0/requirements.txt#L6

Let's upgrade hacking to >= 3.0.1 and < 3.1.0 so that it supports python3.8
correctly. The newer hacking also triggered new errors which are
fixed in this review as well:
./tools/render-ansible-tasks.py:113:25: F841 local variable 'e' is assigned to but never used
./tools/yaml-validate.py:541:19: F999 '...'.format(...) has unused arguments at position(s): 2
./tools/render-ansible-tasks.py:126:1: E305 expected 2 blank lines after class or function definition, found 1
./tools/yaml-validate.py:33:1: E305 expected 2 blank lines after class or function definition, found 1
./container_config_scripts/tests/test_nova_statedir_ownership.py:35:1: E305 expected 2 blank lines after class or function definition, found 0

Also make sure we exclude .tox and __pycache__ from flake8 as well

We also need to change the lower-constraint requirements to make them
py3.8 compatible. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1886298
cffi==1.14.0
greenlet==0.4.15
MarkupSafe==1.1.0
paramiko==2.7.1

Suggested-By: Yatin Karel <ykarel@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic280ce9a51f26d165d4e93ba0dc0c47cdf8d7961
Closes-Bug: #1895093

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-21 19:25:16.000000000', 'message': 'Make Gnocchi connection pool configurable

When Cloudkitty is collecting data from gnocchi, it opens many
connections to Gnocchi to parallelize the requests; as Cloudkitty
starts to fetch the responses from gnocchi, it releases the
connections to the pool until it starts to overflow (reaching the
default limit of the Requests connection pool). This behavior
causes no problems, but prevents the reuse of connections.

To mitigate this problem and optimize the use of connections, we
propose to add a new configuration in Gnocchi collector and
fetcher to set the connection pool max size when connecting to
gnocchi.The new configuration is `connection_pool_max_size`
and you can configure it in the `cloudkitty.conf` file like:

```
[fetcher_gnocchi]
        .
        .
        .
connection_pool_max_size = 50[collector_gnocchi]
        .
        .
        .
connection_pool_max_size = 50
```

The default value is defined by the `requests` library which is 10.

commit_message:
Make Gnocchi connection pool configurable

When CloudKitty is collecting data from Gnocchi, it opens many
connections to Gnocchi to parallelize the requests; as CloudKitty starts
to fetch the responses from Gnocchi, it releases the connections to the
pool until it starts to overflow (reaching the default limit of the
Requests connection pool). This behavior causes no problems, but
prevents the reuse of connections.

To mitigate this problem and optimize the use of connections, we propose
to add a new configuration in Gnocchi collector and fetcher to set the
connection pool maximum size when connecting to Gnocchi. The new
configuration is `http_pool_maxsize` and you can configure it in the
`cloudkitty.conf` file like:

```
[fetcher_gnocchi]
http_pool_maxsize = 50

[collector_gnocchi]
http_pool_maxsize = 50
```

The default value is defined by the `requests` library which is 10.

Change-Id: I3ee22984dc87b505924e1711bc723bc1c5f160a5
Story: 2008125
Task: 40847

commit_message:
configure-swap: Always use dd and limit swap size to 1024MB

A recent kernel update in Fedora has highlighted that fallocate produced
swap files on ext4 partions are no longer accepted by swapon:

swapon failed if the swap file is created by fallocate in ext4 partition
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1827115

This change assumes that all distros will eventually encounter this and
removes the fallocate task from the role and defaults to using dd. As
this is considerably slower the overall size of the swap file is reduced
to 1024MB.

Change-Id: I5ce9064a5546d85ab6f41c4e60aa56fa56ff47c1

subject: Adjust the usage of Ansible forks
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 8833, 'name': 'Rabi Mishra', 'email': 'ramishra@redhat.com', 'username': 'rabi'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25877, 'name': 'Luke Short', 'email': 'ekultails@gmail.com', 'username': 'ekultails'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-07-16 14:51:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-07-16 15:33:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-07-16 19:00:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-07-16 19:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-07-16 19:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[RFC] This latest patch set allows the environment variable ANSIBLE_FORKS to override the number of forks (the same variable that Ansible itself uses). If this were to be backported to Train, the environment variable would have to be set in the mistral-execution container. To avoid that, we may want to instead create an --ansible-forks argument in python-tripleoclient. I am open to suggestions/feedback.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-07-20 14:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-07-20 15:08:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

I will send a new patchset that will expose --ansible-forks as a new argument in tripleoclient (instead of relying on an environment variable that will most likely not be picked up from within the mistral-execution container).'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-07-29 16:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-08-11 14:52:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

So I don't believe we should be uncapped because there's a deminishing return for larger number of forks due to ram and process context switching.  I tested something similar and found that cpucount * 2 results in a better results for free strategies vs linear likely because there's less process churn when checking busy workers."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-08-12 08:43:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> So I don't believe we should be uncapped

Are we saying it's not capped with the number of hosts when using free strategy and the ansible recommended one of cpu_count * 4 is only valid for linear?

I would prefer exposing number of ansible forks as a heat parameter (whatever default we decide), which can be changed as deployments scale out."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-08-12 13:07:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm saying capping works better for all. Lower numbers are actually better due to the context switching.  cpu * 4 is probably fine, i tested cpu*2 and it was faster than the existing cpu * 10.

Additionally I don't think a heat param is appropriate for this setting.  A cli option is likely the correct target because we don't set any of the ansible settings via heat"}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-09-10 19:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Closing in favor of: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/748718/'}]

commit_message:
Adjust the usage of Ansible forks

It is now more conservative about using up the available Undercloud
RAM. It can also no longer exceed 100 forks when automatically
deteremined. The forks can be overridden by the "ANSIBLE_FORKS"
environment variable.

Change-Id: I358d63dd57de9be3bf11e091075d0163ec5afe71
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

The devstack-plugin-zeromq is retired, see

to fix Zuul configuration.

commit_message:
Remove experimental job legacy-tempest-dsvm-zeromq-multibackend

The devstack-plugin-zeromq is retired, see
https://review.opendev.org/748700. Remove this experimental job
to fix Zuul configuration.

Change-Id: I37c028ab063ec9127f02dd479cae49da8bffb11b
(cherry picked from commit 0e72ffa9872d2dc0f739a1fc1860e59f5865443c)

commit_message:
Release final python-blazarclient for victoria

Final victoria client lib release for the September 10 deadline.

Please leave +1 if we are all set and can proceed. Leave a -1 if we
need to wait a little bit longer for something final to loand,
then update with a better commit hash to use for the release when
ready.

Patches with no response will be approved by September 14.

Change-Id: I280a1f8188cb9612ada09ab11c4f7842a20958f8
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

default ones.

how to implement auditing in OpenStack deployments.
Custom paste files are copied from following path:
{{ node_custom_config }}/{{ service_name }}/{{ service_name }}-api-paste.ini

commit_message:
Support for custom API paste files

Implements mechanism of deploying custom API paste files overriding
default ones.
API paste files configures API requests pipelining and provide only way
how to implement auditing in OpenStack deployments.
Custom paste files are copied from following path:
{{ node_custom_config }}/{{ project_name }}/{{ project_name }}-api-paste.ini;
in case of override for neutron-server default api-paste.ini the path may be:
/etc/kolla/config/neutron/neutron-api-paste.ini
(in case the {{ node_custom_config }} points to /etc/kolla/config ).

Change-Id: I93e333667add275f353b213043de1c713f049167
Blueprint: custom-paste

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-08 14:42:21.000000000', 'message': "post live migration: don't call Neutron needlessly

In bug 1879787, the call to network_api.get_instance_nw_info() in
_post_live_migration() on the source compute manager eventually calls
out to the Neutron REST API. If this fails, the exception is
unhandled, and the migrating instance - which is fully running on the
destination at this point - will never be updated in the database.
This update normally happens later in
post_live_migration_at_destination().

The network_info variable obtained from get_instance_nw_info() is used
for two things: notifications - which aren't critical - and unplugging
the instance's vifs on the source - which is very important!

It turns out that at the time of the get_instance_nw_info() call, the
network info in the instance info cache is still valid for unplugging
the source vifs. The port bindings on the destination are only
activated by the network_api.migrate_instance_start() [1] call that
happens shortly *after* the problematic get_instance_nw_info() call.
In other words, get_instance_nw_info() will always return the source
ports. Because of that, we can replace it with a call to
instance.get_network_info().

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/d9e04c4ff0b1a9c3383f1848dc846e93030d83cb/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L2493-L2522

Change-Id: If0fbae33ce2af198188c91638afef939256c2556
Closes-bug: 1879787
(cherry picked from commit 6488a5dfb293831a448596e2084f484dd0bfa916)
"}]
commit_message:
post live migration: don't call Neutron needlessly

In bug 1879787, the call to network_api.get_instance_nw_info() in
_post_live_migration() on the source compute manager eventually calls
out to the Neutron REST API. If this fails, the exception is
unhandled, and the migrating instance - which is fully running on the
destination at this point - will never be updated in the database.
This update normally happens later in
post_live_migration_at_destination().

The network_info variable obtained from get_instance_nw_info() is used
for two things: notifications - which aren't critical - and unplugging
the instance's vifs on the source - which is very important!

It turns out that at the time of the get_instance_nw_info() call, the
network info in the instance info cache is still valid for unplugging
the source vifs. The port bindings on the destination are only
activated by the network_api.migrate_instance_start() [1] call that
happens shortly *after* the problematic get_instance_nw_info() call.
In other words, get_instance_nw_info() will always return the source
ports. Because of that, we can replace it with a call to
instance.get_network_info().

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/d9e04c4ff0b1a9c3383f1848dc846e93030d83cb/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L2493-L2522

Change-Id: If0fbae33ce2af198188c91638afef939256c2556
Closes-bug: 1879787
(cherry picked from commit 6488a5dfb293831a448596e2084f484dd0bfa916)

commit_message:
Use bool filter when checking use_default_templates var

extra_vars are passed as strings in older ansible-runner versions
and would result in wrong boolean value.

This regression downstream has been caused by
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737677/

Related BZ: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1876999

Change-Id: Ie9119d2e6ac6b03c283a535b0445e83a2b564dbf

commit_message:
Add support for image_format/disk_fomats configuration

This is useful to avoid callers use glance::config for the sole
reason of configuring the allowed disk_formats, which can be
customized to filter out values when using particular backends,
like RBD, which perform suboptimally with certain image formats.

Change-Id: I0f343321d43efa5e4a4274f01a4592a8fcd92417

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I2925b757166177068cc17a5afb07d65d821cad37

_post_live_migration() on the destination host has a call to
self.network_api.get_instance_nw_info(), which eventually ends up

commit_message:
Add regression test for bug 1879787

_post_live_migration() on the destination host has a call to
self.network_api.get_instance_nw_info(), which eventually ends up
calling the Neutron REST API (via
nova.network.neutron.API._build_network_info_model()). Any exceptions
in that call are unhandled. This patch adds a test that assert the
broken behavior. The fix is in the subsequent patch.

Change-Id: Ic5760a0fd2d30c6aaf819bfd7506ad092871de10
(cherry picked from commit 81a44384a983ad9759454260a54a1d88375408cf)

commit_message:
Bump taskflow version

Taskflow 4.4.0 contains essential fix for jobboard behaviour on
Storage failure [1].

Also add jobboard_redis_sentinel parameter to allow usage sentinel
for Redis jobboard. Support of this also appear in 4.4.0 version.

[1] - https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/taskflow/unreleased.html#bug-fixes

Change-Id: I48245b3322b0f2e5f2c11594a15632501a7e4086

commit_message:
Implement the first half of OSC share snapshots commands

In this patch we add openstack commands for:
share snapshot create
share snapshot delete
share snapshot show
share snapshot set
share snapshot unset
share snapshot list

Partially-implements bp openstack-client-support

Change-Id: Idfe2033016f333da0169fd032ff95bf868099f70

commit_message:
Reject resize operation for accelerator

When resize with a new flavor with accelerator, we should raise
forbidden exception to reject the resize operation.
Add related unit test.
Follow up the comment:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/715326/22/nova/compute/api.py@3907

Conflicts:
  nova/compute/api.py
  nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(brinzhang): Conflicts are due to change
eef4b5435e7cdfe53ee9d9265d96c7dd278d9e93 ("api: Reject
non-spawn operations for vTPM") which modified the same code.

Add 'extra_specs={}' as a request parameter in test_resize_quota_check()
in nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py. Actually this change is
required due to not having patch
I147bf4d95e6d86ff1f967a8ce37260730f21d236 in stable ussuri.

Co-Authored-By: Wenping Song <songwenping@inspur.com>

Closes-Bug: #1893751

Change-Id: Ie20a620588e3b0d18055c34ec7671e91e6bf6ee0
(cherry picked from commit 97267fc05c60b60761ebe8ec2773e8920148ae06)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-24 14:55:42.000000000', 'message': 'Move confirm resize under semaphore

The 'ResourceTracker.update_available_resource' periodic task builds
usage information for the current host by inspecting instances and
in-progress migrations, combining the two. Specifically, it finds all
instances that are not in the 'DELETED' or 'SHELVED_OFFLOADED' state,
calculates the usage from these, then finds all in-progress migrations
for the host that don't have an associated instance (to prevent double
accounting) and includes the usage for these.

In addition to the periodic task, the 'ResourceTracker' class has a
number of helper functions to make or drop claims for the inventory
generated by the 'update_available_resource' periodic task as part of
the various instance operations. These helpers naturally assume that
when making a claim for a particular instance or migration, there
shouldn't already be resources allocated for same. Conversely, when
dropping claims, the resources should currently be allocated. However,
the check for *active* instances and *in-progress* migrations in the
periodic task means we have to be careful in how we make changes to a
given instance or migration record. Running the periodic task between
such an operation and an attempt to make or drop a claim can result in
TOCTOU-like races.

This generally isn't an issue: we use the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE'
semaphore to prevent the periodic task running while we're claiming
resources in helpers like 'ResourceTracker.instance_claim' and we make
our changes to the instances and migrations within this context. There
is one exception though: the 'drop_move_claim' helper. This function is
used when dropping a claim for either a cold migration, a resize or a
live migration, and will drop usage from either the source host (based
on the "old" flavor) for a resize confirm or the destination host (based
on the "new" flavor) for a resize revert or live migration rollback.
Unfortunately, while the function itself is wrapped in the semaphore, no
changes to the state or the instance or migration in question are
protected by it.

Consider the confirm resize case, which we're addressing here. If we
mark the migration as 'confirmed' before running 'drop_move_claim', then
the periodic task running between these steps will not account for the
usage on the source since the migration is allegedly 'confirmed'. The
call to 'drop_move_claim' will then result in the tracker dropping usage
that we're no longer accounting for. This "set migration status before
dropping usage" is the current behaviour for both same-cell and
cross-cell resize, via the 'ComputeManager.confirm_resize' and
'ComputeManager.confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source' functions,
respectively. We could reverse those calls and run 'drop_move_claim'
before marking the migration as 'confirmed', but while our usage will be
momentarily correct, the periodic task running between these steps will
re-add the usage we just dropped since the migration isn't yet
'confirmed'. The correct solution is to close this gap between setting
the migration status and dropping the move claim to zero. We do this by
putting both operations behind the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE', just
like the claim operations.

Change-Id: I26b050c402f5721fc490126e9becb643af9279b4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878

commit_message:
Move confirm resize under semaphore

The 'ResourceTracker.update_available_resource' periodic task builds
usage information for the current host by inspecting instances and
in-progress migrations, combining the two. Specifically, it finds all
instances that are not in the 'DELETED' or 'SHELVED_OFFLOADED' state,
calculates the usage from these, then finds all in-progress migrations
for the host that don't have an associated instance (to prevent double
accounting) and includes the usage for these.

In addition to the periodic task, the 'ResourceTracker' class has a
number of helper functions to make or drop claims for the inventory
generated by the 'update_available_resource' periodic task as part of
the various instance operations. These helpers naturally assume that
when making a claim for a particular instance or migration, there
shouldn't already be resources allocated for same. Conversely, when
dropping claims, the resources should currently be allocated. However,
the check for *active* instances and *in-progress* migrations in the
periodic task means we have to be careful in how we make changes to a
given instance or migration record. Running the periodic task between
such an operation and an attempt to make or drop a claim can result in
TOCTOU-like races.

This generally isn't an issue: we use the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE'
semaphore to prevent the periodic task running while we're claiming
resources in helpers like 'ResourceTracker.instance_claim' and we make
our changes to the instances and migrations within this context. There
is one exception though: the 'drop_move_claim' helper. This function is
used when dropping a claim for either a cold migration, a resize or a
live migration, and will drop usage from either the source host (based
on the "old" flavor) for a resize confirm or the destination host (based
on the "new" flavor) for a resize revert or live migration rollback.
Unfortunately, while the function itself is wrapped in the semaphore, no
changes to the state or the instance or migration in question are
protected by it.

Consider the confirm resize case, which we're addressing here. If we
mark the migration as 'confirmed' before running 'drop_move_claim', then
the periodic task running between these steps will not account for the
usage on the source since the migration is allegedly 'confirmed'. The
call to 'drop_move_claim' will then result in the tracker dropping usage
that we're no longer accounting for. This "set migration status before
dropping usage" is the current behaviour for both same-cell and
cross-cell resize, via the 'ComputeManager.confirm_resize' and
'ComputeManager.confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source' functions,
respectively. We could reverse those calls and run 'drop_move_claim'
before marking the migration as 'confirmed', but while our usage will be
momentarily correct, the periodic task running between these steps will
re-add the usage we just dropped since the migration isn't yet
'confirmed'. The correct solution is to close this gap between setting
the migration status and dropping the move claim to zero. We do this by
putting both operations behind the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE', just
like the claim operations.

Change-Id: I26b050c402f5721fc490126e9becb643af9279b4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878

[{'created': '2020-08-17 14:53:39.000000000', 'message': 'func: Introduce a server_expected_state kwarg to InstanceHelperMixin._live_migrate

Useful when testing live migration failures that leave the server in an
non ACTIVE state. This change also renames the migration_final_status
arg to migration_expected_state within the method to keep it in line
with _create_server.

NOTE(artom): This is to facilitate subsequent backports of live
migration regression tests and bug fixes.

Change-Id: Ie0852a89fc9423a92baa7c29a8806c0628cae220
(cherry picked from commit e70ddd621cb59a8845a4241387d8a49e443b7b69)

commit_message:
func: Introduce a server_expected_state kwarg to InstanceHelperMixin._live_migrate

Useful when testing live migration failures that leave the server in an
non ACTIVE state. This change also renames the migration_final_status
arg to migration_expected_state within the method to keep it in line
with _create_server.

NOTE(artom): This is to facilitate subsequent backports of live
migration regression tests and bug fixes.

Change-Id: Ie0852a89fc9423a92baa7c29a8806c0628cae220
(cherry picked from commit e70ddd621cb59a8845a4241387d8a49e443b7b69)

commit_message:
Release final python-octaviaclient for victoria

Final victoria client lib release for the September 10 deadline.

Please leave +1 if we are all set and can proceed. Leave a -1 if we
need to wait a little bit longer for something final to loand,
then update with a better commit hash to use for the release when
ready.

Patches with no response will be approved by September 14.

Change-Id: I2dc6bec2699427ca630958252bedc978223157c2

commit_message:
Add support for nftables

This patch adds support for nftables (an iptables replacement) to
the devstack plugin and the amphora agent.

Change-Id: I9e2c4d6e68da67d68c6dfeb3b47edd600d1ba397

image builders. In order to do that gracefully we need to pause all
image builds on nb04 so that nb01 and nb02 take up the slack. Then once

commit_message:
Pause image builds on nb04.opendev.org

We'd like to delete nb04.opendev.org and go back to running two x86
image builders. In order to do that gracefully we need to pause all
image builds on nb04 so that nb01 and nb02 take up the slack. Then once
nb04's images are no longer in use they can be deleted and the builder
can be removed.

Change-Id: Ibe00252de4f602a6c9f48ad1799d844710ddc6dc

commit_message:
Alerta image

Resolve the vulerability issues from original Alerta docker image
- reference image from Python 3.7 to ubuntu:bionic
- Set Alerta Server version to 8.0.2
- Remove non-core plugins and features

Change-Id: I4743ba55bbea7338040670249c6b88afb5df8d7c

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate tox jobs to to focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-fo$

Change-Id: Ib40ae3b26e5db16c70d16749c0fe0984ff413fa4
Story: #2007865
Task: #40186

commit_message:
Add sorting_method=none to get a consistent node order

You probably don't want this in prod, but it can be useful for
development and review.

Change-Id: I7c828a4e0c490a32434facdb68cbc2027e787443

commit_message:
Improve IPv6 documentation for access rules

This patch improves the access rules API documentation
to include IPv6 information that was missing.
It includes a note on user guide and changes an access list
example to IPv6.

Change-Id: I5a9ff4e3c8a70cb0b14caa39f5f17740b17b719a
Closes-Bug: #1705045
Signed-off-by: Douglas Viroel <viroel@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add Python3 wallaby unit tests

This is an automatically generated patch to ensure unit testing
is in place for all the of the tested runtimes for wallaby.

See also the PTI in governance [1].

[1]: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

'}, {'created': '2016-12-22 15:53:53.000000000', 'message': "add zvm migration object

zvm is a out of tree driver which we want to be in tree in the future

zvm have CI here:
